title: AI-readiness working group charter
text:
Status (New/Update): New
Group Name: HUPO-PSI AI-readiness Working Group
Chair: Tine Claeys (tineclae.claeys at ugent dot be), VIB - Ghent University, Ghent, Belgium
Co-Chairs:

Samuel Wein (samuel.wein at uni-tuebingen dot de), University of T√ºbingen ‚Äì OpenMS, T√ºbingen, Germany
Ralf Gabriels (ralf.gabriels at ugent dot be), Ghent University ‚Äì VIB, Ghent, Belgium

Secretary: Vacant






The goal of the PSI-AI working group is to bridge the gap between artificial intelligence and public proteomics data. We focus on two complementary goals. The first is to make public proteomics data suitable for AI applications. The second is to support and standardize the use of AI in workflows that generate new data. We work toward these goals through the use of community standards and reproducible and accessible pipelines. Our aim is to integrate with, not duplicate, existing infrastructure.




Goal 1: Publish a review on good reprocessing practices in large-scale proteomics
Goal 2: Curate a benchmark corpus of selected public datasets in homogeneous format
Goal 3: Collaborate with EuBIC-MS for the development of a retroactive metadata annotation pipeline
Goal 4: Development of a community-driven and open-access reprocessing workflow
Goal 5: Collaborate with existing benchmarking community efforts such as Proteobench to benchmark AI pipelines
Goal 6: Collaborate with existing educational community efforts such as ProteomicsML to educate users on AI applications within proteomics

title: AI-readiness working group charter
text:
The goal of the PSI-AI working group is to bridge the gap between artificial intelligence and public proteomics data. We focus on two complementary goals. The first is to make public proteomics data suitable for AI applications. The second is to support and standardize the use of AI in workflows that generate new data. We work toward these goals through the use of community standards and reproducible and accessible pipelines. Our aim is to integrate with, not duplicate, existing infrastructure.




Goal 1: Publish a review on good reprocessing practices in large-scale proteomics
Goal 2: Curate a benchmark corpus of selected public datasets in homogeneous format
Goal 3: Collaborate with EuBIC-MS for the development of a retroactive metadata annotation pipeline
Goal 4: Development of a community-driven and open-access reprocessing workflow
Goal 5: Collaborate with existing benchmarking community efforts such as Proteobench to benchmark AI pipelines
Goal 6: Collaborate with existing educational community efforts such as ProteomicsML to educate users on AI applications within proteomics

title: PSI-AI
text: The PSI AI-readiness working group bridges the gap between public proteomics data and the use of artificial intelligence. We focus on making proteomics data AI-ready while standardizing AI workflows that generate new data through community standards and reproducible pipelines.

title: PSI-AI
text: The PSI AI-readiness working group bridges the gap between public proteomics data and the use of artificial intelligence. We focus on making proteomics data AI-ready while standardizing AI workflows that generate new data through community standards and reproducible pipelines.

title: PSI-AI
text:
Key Objectives


üìä Data Accessibility Enhance metadata annotation for AI discoverability
üîÑ Harmonize Raw Data Formats Convert to open formats (mzML, mzPeak)
‚ö° Streamlined Data Reprocessing Lightweight ML-ready data processing workflows


üéØ Benchmark Resources Curated datasets and methods for AI development
üìã Best Practices Ethical and effective reproducibility standards
ü§ù Community Standards AI model frameworks and HUPO-PSI integration

title: PSI-AI
text:
About This Resource
This site serves as the dynamic hub for PSI-AI working group outputs, including:
üìö Living Documentation Guidelines and standards that evolve with the field
üìã Best Practice Guides Crowd-sourced recommendations
üîó Curated Links Community-curated resources and tools






NoteEveryone can contribute!



Whether through commenting, writing documentation, sharing resources, or joining working groups - this platform thrives on community participation.

title: PSI-AI
text:
Get Involved


ü§ù Contribute content

Submit documentation
Share best practices
Review community submissions
Provide feedback



üí¨ Join discussions

Comment on proposals
Attend community calls
Participate in the working group task forces
Share project experiences




Ways to Participate

Working Group Charter - Learn about our mission and structure
Community Surveys - Help shape priorities and direction
Collaborative Writing - Co-author documentation and guidelines
Resource Sharing - Contribute tools, datasets, and workflows
Peer Review - Help validate and improve community contributions







Note



Ready to Start? Join our efforts to make proteomics data more accessible and useful for the AI/ML community. Every contribution, no matter how small, helps advance the field.

title: Co-chairs
text:
Co-chairs
PSI-AI is led by a team of co-chairs who coordinate the working group‚Äôs strategy, prioritization, and delivery across the HUPO-PSI community. They ensure alignment with other PSI working groups and external stakeholders, and facilitate consensus on standards, guidelines, and resources that make proteomics data and workflows fit for modern AI/ML use.







Tine Claeys

VIB / Ghent University (BE)






Samuel Wein

University of T√ºbingen / OpenMS (DE)






Ralf Gabriels

VIB / Ghent University (BE)






Members
PSI-AI members form an international, cross-disciplinary community spanning proteomics standards development, computational proteomics, software engineering, repositories, benchmarking and reporting, curated dataset development, and ethics and privacy expertise to ensure interoperable, reproducible, compliant, and AI-ready proteomics.







Ben Neely

National Institute of Standards and Technology (US)






Ina Devos

University of Antwerp / VITO (BE)






Jonas Scheid

University Hospital T√ºbingen (DE)






Kevin Yang

University of Michigan (US)






Lisa Boatner

Chan Zuckerberg Initiative (US)






Parag Mallick

Stanford University / Nautilus Biotechnology (US)






Patricia Cervera de la Cruz

PHG Foundation (UK) / Ghent University (BE)






Thomas Naake

National Metrology Institute (DE)




PSI-AI is strengthened by many additional contributors across the wider proteomics and data standards community whose insights and efforts support this work, even if they are not individually shown here.


Join PSI-AI
PSI-AI welcomes participation from the wider community, including researchers, tool developers, repository teams, standards contributors, and ethics and legal experts. To get involved, please contact us at info at psi-ai dot org.
